Hi Mercy,
Here are some documents you may find helpful in addition to Michelle’s great answer!
•   This is a sample policy from the City of Johnson City, Tennessee. It details the conditions and stipulations that apply to special events conducted within the city limits. icma.org/Documents/QuestionAnswer/Document/10360
•   This document is the Reno Municipal Code regarding special events in the city. It includes a definition of “special event” and information on how they are handled. icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/12983
•   This is a similar previously answered question with over 5 different highly detailed answers on how different local governments are dealing with this issue. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/22390
I hope you find these links helpful as you look for a solution that will work for your local government. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
rsaywitz@icma.org

Mercy - Here is a link to the City of Dublin, Ohio event permit page.  This has our application and a guidebook that explains fees and requirements.  Several years ago we completed a cost of services study to determine direct and indirect costs for all the services we provide.  It is updated each year and as a result, some of our fees are adjusted.  Hope this is helpful.  Let me know if you have any questions.  http://dublinohiousa.gov/events/event-guidebook-event-application/

author: Mercy Montgomery
text:
Currently, the City of Hamilton, OH conducts event costing using a two step process: 

Event applications are filed by individuals/groups with our volunteer and events coordinator.
Applications are sent to City Departments and Divisions to estimate costs incurred by the event.

We're hoping to transition to a flat-rate fee structure based on event attendance, type, and duration.
Any sample policies or advice you can share would be greatly appreciated!
Best,
Mercy Montgomery
title: City Event Policy and Fee Structure
